prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - mosaic 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaic of the cold, cluster forming clump G337.342-00.119

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to map the clump G337.342-0.119 at sufficient sensitivity, angular resolution, and spectral resolution to reliably measure its column density distribution and gas kinematics. The best compromise between continuum and line sensitivity for this purpose, and the availability of suitable molecular lines, occurs at frequencies near 270 GHz (band 6).
We require sufficient sensitivity to reliably detect the mean in the column density PDF for G337.342-0.119. Based on theoretical predictions, the mean column density is expected to be ~17 x 10^21 cm-2. Thus, for a 3-sigma detection of this column density, we require a column density sensitivity of at least 5 x 10^21 cm-2. Using the measured Herschel dust temperature of ~15 K, a gas to dust mass ratio of 100, and dust emissivity coefficient (kappa at 1.2mm) of 0.8 cm2/g, this column density corresponds to a 1 mm flux density of 0.18 mJy/beam. This requested continuum sensitivity with produce a 3 sigma detection of the faintest emission we aim to measure.
Assuming a core radius of 0.05 pc and a dust temperature of 15 K, this flux sensitivity corresponds to a mass sensitivity of ~2Msun. Since this core mass is comparable to the peak in the core mass function for typical molecular clouds, we will easily detect any star-forming cores if present.
With this continuum sensitivity, we can achieve a line brightness sensitivity of 0.28 K per 0.5 km/s channel. From MALT90, we know the brightness temperatures of density-tracing species like HCO+ and HNC (1-0) are ~ T_B = 2 K in a 38" beam (per 0.5 km/s channel). Since the densities are high, especially toward star-forming cores, the 1 mm (3-2) lines are likely to be comparable. In fact, they are likely to be brighter, since the single-dish emission is almost certainly beam-diluted, and the cores will have high densities. Moreover, in cold, dense clouds the ground state 1-0 transitions are often self-absorbed. The 1 mm lines, therefore, are likely to be brighter than 2 K. Indeed, excitation models suggest that for conservative values of the abundances, the core brightness temperatures will be > 2 K. Thus, the requested sensitivity will be more than sufficient to reliably detect the line emission toward the star-forming cores.

Our correlator setup is driven by the requirement to have sufficient velocity resolution to resolve several key diagnostic lines toward any star-forming cores within the clump. Since one of our key science goals is to determine if the cores are self-gravitating, we need to reliably measure their line widths in an optically thin gas tracer.
Our continuum sensitivity corresponds to a mass sensitivity of 2 Msun. If such a core was in viral equilibrium and assuming a radius of 0.05 pc, its line width would be ~0.4 km/s (higher mass cores of the same size would have larger line widths). Thus, we set the minimum velocity resolution for the most important spectral windows to be 0.5 km/s (which corresponds to a bandwidth of 234 MHz). Since setting all the spectral windows to this resolution produces a data rate higher than 12 MB/s, we use a combination of spectral averaging and broader bandwidths in the other windows that contain additional relevant transitions (these are marked as "continuum" windows in the spectral setup).
We choose to allocate 8 spectral windows in dual polarization mode across the base-bands. A critical diagnostic is to choose an optically thick line and its much optically thinner isotopologue, since chemical effects are minimized. Thus, we choose a set-up that focussed on the optically thick transition (HCO+ 3-2), as well as its optically thin isotopologue (HC18O+ 3-2). For these lines we require a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s - they will provide reliably measurements of the velocities and line widths. For the additional 6 spectral windows we have placed them to cover other important spectral lines (i.e HNC, 15N2H+, CH3OH, NHD2, H2CS, SO2) that probe a range in critical densities, excitation energies, and opacities. For these lines we will achieve a velocity resolution of 1 km/s, which is more than adequate to detect (and potentially resolve) the emission.
This spectral setup will result in an aggregate bandwidth of 5.625 GHz, which is required to reliably detect the continuum emission to our requested sensitivity.

To reliably measure the column density distribution within G337.342-0.119 requires observations that probe spatial scales down to the expected fragmentation scale (~0.05pc). At the distance to this clump, the most compact configuration in Band 6 provides an angular resolution of 1.27" which corresponds to a physical size scale of 0.07pc. Resolving down to this spatial scale is necessary to both measure the small-scale structure and to identify any star-forming cores that be located within the clump. This angular resolution will match our ALMA cycle 0 and 1 mosaics of G0.253+0.016 (both have angular resolutions of 0.07 pc): for a reliable comparison, it is important that these two datasets are similar.
To cover the extent of the column density peaks within this clump requires two separate mosaics, with 124 and 149 pointings (see Fig.~1). This science goal corresponds to mosaic 1 with 124 pointings.
To address our science goals of detecting the large-scale continuum and line emission from clump as a whole also requires the inclusion of the ACA. From our previous ALMA cycle 0 and cycle 1 observations of G0.253+0.016, we have found the inclusion of large-scale emission critical to reliably trace the large-scale dust continuum and gas motions.
Combining the ACA and ALMA will reveal the dust and gas distribution within G337.342-0.119 on all spatial scales continuously from 0.07 to 5 pc. This is only feasible due to the unique capabilities of the ACA and the large mosaicing capabilities of ALMA.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - mosaic 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 mosaic of the cold, cluster forming clump G337.342-00.119

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have identified a cold, dense, high-mass molecular clump, G337.342-0.119, that is likely a progenitor to a high-mass cluster. With a turbulent Mach number that is intermediate between those measured in the Galactic Disk and the extreme Central Molecular Zone of our Galaxy, G337.342-0.119 represents an excellent clump in which to test turbulence theories that make predictions for the gas distribution before star formation has begun. We propose to obtain a 1mm mosaic of its dust continuum and line emission to determine the cloud- to core-scale column density distribution and gas kinematics. With the dust continuum observations we will test quantitative predictions of turbulent theory, specifically, the shape, mean, and dispersion of its column density probability distribution function and the theorteically predicted, environmentally dependent volume density threshold for star formation. Additionally, with the line observations we will investigate whether individual cores are gravitationally bound. Confirmation of these theories would demonstrate that turbulence dominates the initial gas structure in cluster-forming clumps.
